name: Gremlins, Inc.
developer: Charlie Oscar Lima Tango Interactive Entertainment
description: This is an intense strategy board game in a steampunk world of corrupt capitalist gremlins who compete for money, political power and prestige. Save and invest, steal and extort, arrest and get arrested – in single-player and multiplayer, with ranks and ladders, team mode and spectator mode.

Gremlins Inc.  is a crazy steampunk card game that has a focus on making money through movements on a gameboard. You get six random cards, and you play against other people or AI and try to win by ending with the most score resource.  You can play by tweaking various amounts of score limits, or whoever is ahead at the end of a certain number of turns, for instance. There are a lot of various rules that are included in the game, based on spaces you land on, and cards with varying effects, depending on what cards you end up playing, or getting as you go around board game style spaces. You really have to watch what is going on, and employ your own strategies each round on which cards to keep, and which ones to use for movement, or to hold for later on in the game. The cards you play have the movement amounts, as opposed to dice, but dice play a 'roll' *cough cough* in certain events in the game as well.    Pros:
A surprisingly balanced chaos of backstabbing and risk management within a very well polished online board game.

This game a great, well polished, original digital board game that I would highly recommend if you are okay with winning or losing based on the draw of the cards, or the roll of the dice. There are strategic elements, decision making, and the ability to screw over other players, but ultimately, this game does come down to chance - draw good cards and roll good dice, and you will have a massive advantage. The game is well presented and stylish, with good tutorials and game help, it's surprisingly easy to get the hang of. While it might be scary at first glance, the systems are all very logical and consistent. It can be frustrating if you are playing against AI and get many bad rolls - you can lose to the AI through no fault of your own, simply because the AI got better luck than you. But multiplayer is where this game really shines, as you can laugh about being lucky or unlucky with your friends. All in all, I've had a great time with Gremlins, Inc.

My expectations for this were pretty low, but I have to say I ended up being impressed. This game is great. It lets you screw with the other players and they can do the same to you. The multiplayer is also easy to get into and not intimidating.

+Polished Gameplay +Excellent Music and Sounds +No microtransactions or card collection. Everyone owns the same set of cards. +Just the right amount of RNG (6 face dice rolls) +Excellent art work +Strategy and long term planning is rewarding though difficult to achieve +Not a money sink like hearthstone.   -Difficult to pick up as you need to understand the board and cards first. -Require a friend who owns the game for a nicer experience. -Games can get very long though you can set a time limited game (minimum 30 minutes)

I haven't played this for very long I know, however I thought I would let people know how good this game really is. Although I have only played SINGLEPLAYER so far, it's been fun & frustrating (although laughable) when actually trying to win the game! On my second game I was so close to obtaining the required 20 Cogs to win, but as I got to 19 and looked like I was just one play away from winning, my opponent took away 2 of the cards that I needed to use in order to take that win (although either card would have been sufficient!) I won shortly after, but it could have been and should have been earlier, I called my opponent names (won't mention what here lol) then laughed right after.   Brilliant game imo, fun and frustrating and laughable right the way through. The music is good too, the layout and friendly menus make it worth it.   Not sure why the guy earlier complained on how long it takes to win, because you can customize the game to suit your needs, play short game or a longer one, entirely up to you. Perhaps he didn't realise this and lost his temper for the lack of knowledge of the game. But come on, there's a Tutorial for those that can't get into it properly. Plenty fun for any type of player, again imo!

The game is way too random to be labelled a 'strategy' game. Your movement depends on the randomness of drawing cards and victory conditions depend on the randomness of drawing cards. Basically, the game is almost completely random.  That doesn't mean that this is a bad game. If you like randomly chaotic games then this is for you. If you are looking for a strategy game, look elsewhere.  I wish that I could vote one thumb to the left and one thumb to the right but I have to give it a thumbs down for false advertising.

I don't believe I even heard of this game before it was released (and I received a coupon for it in my inventory)... or I just ignored it. At first I was thinking 'nah, not my cup of tea' ... but then I started reading the reviews and accessed the web site to learn more about it and decided to give it a try. 8 hours of play into it now and I have to say, I'm glad I did, I really like it. I'm glad I took the plunge. In-fact, I've been looking around for other similar games (haven't really found any though).   I especially like the pace of the game (i.e. if I need to take a break, I can just walk away for a little while and it will be waiting on my turn when i come back (of course, some times I end up in jail too!) ... although I won't do that if I was playing multi-player.  I keep forgetting I have Chaos Cards available which can really help win the game especially towards the end when the additional malice won't matter anymore. At least that's what I've used them for so far.  I did find that the high contrast option does make it more comfortable and the user interface is nice.   I don't feel I'm quite good enough to try multi-player yet, but it shouldn't be too much longer. I've won some of the easier single-player sessions a couple times, really just trying to learn the ins and outs of it at this point.
